The haar, a damp, grey ghost, drifted in from the North Sea, clinging to the granite bones of Inverurie. It softened the edges of the world, muting the colours of the Garioch and turning the River Don into a slow, silver serpent. Alistair MacLeod stood at his attic window, a mug of tea warming his hands, and watched the town awaken. He drew power from this place, from the ancient confluence of the rivers, from the deep-rooted history sleeping beneath the tarmac and paving stones. His magic was one of stone and water, of whispered words caught on the wind and the subtle turning of the seasons. It was a quiet, enduring craft, much like the landscape that had birthed it.

He took a slow sip of his tea, letting the warmth spread through his chest. The ritual was always the same. Dawn, tea, and a quiet moment to feel the pulse of the world before the noise of the day began. He was trying to scry the surface of his brew, a minor cantrip for divining the day's prospects, when the sound came.

It was distant, but sharp as a flint knife. A single, triumphant, throat-ripping cry that sliced through the morning's calm. *Cock-a-doodle-doo!*

Alistair flinched so violently that hot tea sloshed over his knuckles. The mug clattered against the windowsill, the dark liquid's surface shattering into a hundred chaotic ripples. The image he had been coaxing into view—a vague, pleasant premonition of finding a rare patch of bog myrtle—vanished. In its place, a cold sweat bloomed on his forehead. His heart hammered against his ribs like a trapped bird. The sound, that specific, arrogant fanfare, was a key turning a lock in the deepest, most rusted part of his mind. He could almost feel the phantom prickle of feathers against his skin, the memory of a hard, unblinking eye, the terrifying, percussive strength in a creature that should have been insignificant. He squeezed his eyes shut. It was just a chicken. A stupid, feathered alarm clock. But the rational part of his brain was a tiny, squeaking mouse against the roaring lion of his phobia. He was a wizard, a man who could persuade the standing stones to share their secrets and weave wards from moonlight, and he was utterly, pathetically terrified of cockerels.

He took a few deep, ragged breaths, focusing on the solid feel of the wooden floorboards beneath his slippers. The panic receded, leaving behind the familiar, bitter tang of shame. It was a weakness he had carried since he was a boy, a curse laid not by a rival warlock but by a particularly aggressive Wyandotte on his grandfather's croft. Forty years on, the terror was as potent as ever. He ran his scalded hand under a cold tap, the physical sting a welcome distraction from the psychic one. The day's magic was already soured. Any delicate work was out of the question now; his focus was shot, his connection to the subtle energies of the world frayed by the jolt of primal fear.

Instead, he would do maintenance. A walk to the Bass, the old motte at the edge of town, to check the integrity of the wards. It was simple, grounding work, more about presence and will than intricate spellcasting. He dressed in his usual attire: worn tweed jacket, sturdy walking boots, and a grey flat cap that had seen better decades. To a casual observer, he was just another middle-aged man out for a constitutional, perhaps a local historian or a keen birdwatcher. The truth was far more complex. The wards on the Bass and its smaller cousin weren't to keep people out, but to keep the hill's ancient, slumbering memories in. Inverurie had seen too much history to be left entirely to its own devices. Left untended, echoes of the Battle of Harlaw could bleed into a Tuesday morning market, and the sorrow of ancient Pictish kings could curdle the milk in every fridge in the AB51 postcode. Alistair was a custodian, a magical groundskeeper for the town's soul.

The air outside was thick with the smell of wet earth and diesel fumes from the first of the morning's lorries rumbling down the High Street. He nodded to Mrs. Gable as she put out her bins, exchanging pleasantries about the dreich weather. It was this seamless blend of the mundane and the magical that Alistair cherished. He saw the world in two layers simultaneously: the physical world of granite and rain, and the ethereal one of energy, belief, and memory that flowed through it. But as he approached the foot of the Bass, a wrongness pricked at his senses. It was a discordant note in a familiar symphony, a faint but persistent buzz of something unnatural.

The grass on the ancient mound was a vibrant, almost aggressive green, yet the feeling it gave off was one of sickness. The subtle, humming power that normally resided here, a gentle thrum of stored time, was weak. It felt… choked. As if it were trying to draw breath through a layer of grease. He frowned, his earlier anxieties forgotten and replaced by a growing professional concern. He left the public footpath, his boots sinking into the damp soil as he began to climb, his hands outstretched, palms open, reading the currents of the place. The wrongness grew stronger the higher he went. It was a tacky, slick feeling, an energy that didn't belong in the clean, cold earth of Aberdeenshire. It felt cheap. Disposable.

He found the source near the summit, not in some grand, occult circle, but snagged on a gorse bush that was turning a sickly yellow-brown at the tips. It was a plastic carrier bag. A thin, white one from a budget supermarket chain, flapping listlessly in the breeze. But it wasn't just a piece of litter. Alistair could feel it. The bag was the epicentre of the sickness. It pulsed with a faint, residual magic, a greasy, synthetic aura that made the hairs on his arms stand up. The magic clinging to it was chaotic and hurried, a spell thrown together with no thought for finesse or consequence. It was the magical equivalent of a shouted obscenity in a library.

He crouched, careful not to touch it directly. He nudged the bag with the toe of his boot. It had an unnatural weight to it, and as it shifted, he saw that it wasn't empty. Inside was a desiccated bundle of what looked like wilted herbs, bound together with a cable tie. But the herbs hadn't simply dried out; they had been leeched of all their essence, their magical potential sucked dry and discarded. The plastic bag had been used as some sort of… container. A vessel for a spell. The very idea was anathema to him. Magic was a living thing, it needed to breathe, to be channeled through natural conduits—wood, stone, living water, even bone. To force it into something as sterile and lifeless as polyethylene was a perversion. It was like trying to serve a fine single malt in a dirty plastic cup. No, it was worse. The plastic didn't just contain the magic; it corrupted it, tainting it with its own synthetic nature, leaving a residue that was now poisoning this small, sacred hill.

He looked around, a cold knot of anger tightening in his stomach. Who would do this? What kind of wizard was so lazy, so utterly devoid of respect for the craft, that they would resort to such methods? This wasn't the work of a dark magician, not in the traditional sense. Dark magic had its own terrible grandeur, its own ancient and appalling rules. This was something else. This was careless. It was grubby. It was the magic of someone who didn't care about the mess they left behind, who saw the ancient forces of the world as a convenience to be used and thrown away. He carefully worked the bag free from the gorse thorns with a fallen twig, holding it at arm's length. The flimsy plastic crackled, the sound an insult to the quiet dignity of the hill. He knew, with a certainty that chilled him to the bone, that this was not a one-off. This was a sign of something new, a blight spreading into his world, and it had begun right here, in his town. The fight, he realised, had come to him. And it had arrived in a plastic bag.

He had to neutralise it. Leaving it here would be like leaving a leaky can of spiritual weedkiller on a prize lawn. To simply throw it away in a mortal bin would be even worse; it would end up in a landfill, a festering node of corrupted energy, slowly poisoning acres of land for decades to come. He pinched the handles of the bag between a thumb and forefinger, the rest of his hand curled into a fist as if to ward off contamination. The plastic felt slick and unnervingly warm. He descended the Bass, his mind racing. Fire was out; burning the plastic would only release the tainted spell-stuff into the haar as a foul, magical smoke. He needed to ground it, to earth it, but the hill itself was already sickened. It had to be the river. Water, especially the fast-flowing, ancient water of the Don, was a great purifier. It could dilute, dissolve, and carry away almost any magical stain if you knew how to ask it.

His walk to the riverbank was a forced march through a newly alien landscape. The world he had cherished for its dual nature now seemed rife with potential threats. Every piece of modern detritus looked suspect. A discarded lottery ticket seemed to flutter with a pathetic pulse of desperate hope. The screen of a smartphone, glimpsed over a stranger's shoulder, glowed not just with light but with a frantic, shallow energy. He saw the world through the lens of this new, grubby magic, a magic of instant gratification and disposable power. It was the magic of want, not of need. A magic that used hashtags instead of sigils and believed a viral post held more power than a standing stone. The thought made him feel old, and for the first time in a long time, profoundly tired. His quiet, enduring craft felt fragile, a handmade thing of wood and wool in an age of injection-moulded plastic.

Reaching a secluded bend in the river, where the bank was a tumble of smooth, grey stones, Alistair set to work. He didn't unwrap the profane bundle. To do so would be to release the chaotic spell into the world. Instead, he selected a large, flat stone from the riverbed, its surface worn smooth by centuries of current. It felt clean in his hands, full of the river's patient strength. He placed the plastic bag on the ground and set the heavy river stone on top of it, pinning it. Then he began to speak to the river. It wasn't a shout, but a low, resonant murmur, words in a dialect older than Scots, older even than Gaelic. He wasn't commanding the water; he was requesting its help. He spoke of the unnatural thing, the synthetic poison, the insult to the land. He asked the river to take it, to wash it clean, to carry its essence away to the great, churning indifference of the sea.

He pressed his hands to the river stone, pushing his own energy down, through the rock, and into the plastic-wrapped charm. He guided the river's power, a trickle at first, then a steady flow, into the tacky aura of the spell. The plastic seemed to sag, to lose its unnatural warmth. The sick feeling that emanated from it began to thin, diluted by the clean, cold power of the Don. He felt the spell within the bag unravel, its hastily woven threads dissolving into nothingness. The desiccated herbs inside were now just dead plants. The cable tie was just a loop of plastic. The bag itself was just a bag. The process took almost an hour, and it left him feeling drained and hollowed out. He had essentially performed a magical decontamination, a Hazmat cleanup on a spiritual level. Finally, he lifted the stone, picked up the now-inert bag, and tucked it into his jacket pocket. It would go into the recycling bin now, its mundane fate restored.

Back in the sanctuary of his attic, the world outside felt muted, held at bay by the thick granite walls and the slate roof. The air smelled of old paper, dried herbs, and beeswax. He placed the offending bag on a slate platter he used for examining potentially troublesome artefacts, though it felt absurd to grant the flimsy object such status. It looked pathetic, a piece of rubbish on an altar. Who was behind this? He discounted a rival immediately. Any wizard worthy of the name, even a dark one, would have more pride. This reeked of impatience and ignorance. A teenager, perhaps, dabbling with forces they’d read about on some disreputable corner of the internet? The thought was almost more disturbing than that of a dedicated foe. A malicious wizard you could understand, you could fight. But how did you combat a tide of casual, careless ignorance? It was like trying to have a duel with a leaky faucet.

He knew what he had to do. His own divinatory powers, reliant on subtlety and calm, were useless for the day. The cockerel's cry and the foul magic had seen to that. But he needed answers. He needed to find the source of this blight before more of it seeped into the bones of his town. He would have to use a more direct, more forceful method of scrying. It was risky, especially when his own equilibrium was so compromised, but he had no choice. He would go to the Pictish symbol stone, the one they called the Maiden Stone, which stood in a farmer's field a few miles out of town. It was a formidable repository of ancient power, a deep well of memory and sight. It did not offer up its secrets lightly; consulting it was less like reading a book and more like wrestling with a glacier. But the Maiden Stone saw everything that happened on the land it watched over. If someone in the Garioch was practicing this cheap, synthetic magic, the stone would know. He pulled his flat cap back on, his jaw set. The quiet of his day was broken, the peace of his town threatened. His work as a custodian had just become a great deal more active.

His car, a fifteen-year-old estate that smelled faintly of damp Labrador and dried seaweed, was another of his shields. It was so perfectly ordinary, so deeply unimpressive, that it rendered him invisible. As he drove out of the town centre, heading west, the Garioch unfurled around him, a patchwork of greens and browns beneath the grey sky. Bennachie, the great mountain that dominated the landscape, was a spectral silhouette in the haar, its familiar Mither Tap hidden from view. Normally, this drive would soothe him, reaffirming his connection to the land. Today, every detail seemed to mock that connection. The neatly packaged bales of silage wrapped in gleaming black plastic looked like monstrous mockeries of his work on the Bass. A crisp packet, tumbling in the wind across a ploughed field, seemed to carry its own frantic, insignificant energy. He was seeing the sickness everywhere now.

The Maiden Stone stood alone in its field, cordoned off by a simple wooden fence to protect it from the farmer’s cattle. It was a tall, slender pillar of pinkish granite, weathered by more than a thousand winters, its face carved with the abstract symbols of the Picts—the crescent and V-rod, the mirror and comb—and below them, a strikingly rendered carving of a man caught between two beasts, his hair pulled by a fish-tailed monster. It was a story no one could now read, a warning whose meaning was lost to time. But Alistair didn't need the story; he needed the power. The stone was a deep taproot into the memory of the land. Its consciousness was not human; it was slow, vast, and crystalline. To draw from it was to subject his own fleeting, warm-blooded mind to the pressure of eons.

He leaned on the fence for a long moment, gathering his will. The air here was cleaner, the synthetic buzz from the town fainter, but the memory of it was a stain on his senses. He wasn't approaching the stone as a supplicant. One did not supplicate a mountain. He was approaching it as an equal, in one sense at least. He was the land’s current, thinking mind; the stone was its memory. They were two parts of a whole. He unlatched the simple gate and walked the dozen paces to the stone's base. The grass was short and springy under his boots. He reached out, not to the carved face, but to the rough, unworked side, pressing his palm flat against the cold, gritty surface. He closed his eyes and pushed past the immediate sensations—the cold, the damp, the texture of lichen. He was reaching for the stillness within.

"I am the keeper of this place," he murmured, his voice a low vibration against the stone. "A thread has been woven that is not of the wool of this land. A sound has been made that is not of the wind or the water. It is false. It is rootless. I ask you, stone of the maiden, memory of the Garioch, to show me its shape. Show me the shadow it casts upon the light." He poured his focus into the stone, a sharp, pointed question driven by the force of his will and the authority of his office. He wasn't asking for a favour; he was demanding a report. For a moment, there was nothing but immense, stony silence. Then, the silence fractured.

The connection, when it came, was not a vision behind his eyes but a violent imposition of alien senses. He felt, not saw, the slick, chemical smoothness of a screen. He smelled, not with his nose but in the core of his mind, the cloying sweetness of a scented candle named 'Ocean Breeze' that had never been near an ocean. He heard a cacophony of tinny, compressed music spilling from cheap headphones. And beneath it all, a single, dominant emotion: a whining, desperate boredom, a yearning for something, anything, to happen, to make the world notice. The feeling was sharp, adolescent, and utterly self-absorbed. Then the perspective shifted. He saw the world through the spell-caster's eyes, a brief, nauseating flash of a bedroom, clothes strewn on the floor, a laptop glowing with a website full of gaudy pentagrams and promises of 'REAL MAGICK, FAST!'. He felt the hurried gathering of herbs from a kitchen spice rack—paprika and dried oregano, treated as if they were belladonna and mandrake—and the grubby triumph of stuffing them into the plastic bag, the act itself more important than the intent. Then came a final, powerful impression, not of a person, but of a place: the raw, splintered scent of a new housing development, the chalky taste of plasterboard dust, and the hollow echo of a place with no ghosts, no history, no soul. A blank slate where someone was trying to scribble a new identity.

He tore his hand away from the stone as if burned, stumbling back with a gasp. A wave of vertigo washed over him, the transition from the stone’s geological timescale to his own frantic heartbeat leaving him dizzy and sick. His head throbbed with the residue of the vision's sensory assault. The cheap perfume, the digital noise, the gnawing boredom—it clung to him like greasy smoke. He leaned heavily against the fence, gulping in the clean, damp air, trying to purge the psychic filth from his lungs. It was worse than he'd imagined. This wasn’t an apprentice who had strayed from the path. This was someone who didn't even know there was a path. They were treating magic like a new app, a life-hack, something to be downloaded and consumed without a thought for the consequences. The stone had not given him a name or a face, but it had given him a location and a motive. The blight was coming from one of the new estates ringing the edge of Inverurie, a place where the ancient landscape had been scraped bare. And the motive was the most dangerous and unpredictable of all: a desperate craving to feel special.

The drive back to Inverurie was a purgatory of grey tarmac and phantom sensations. The ghost-smell of cheap 'Ocean Breeze' clung to the back of his throat, and the thumping, synthetic beat he had heard in the vision seemed to echo in the rhythm of his car's engine. The world had been peeled back to reveal a cheap plastic underlayer, and now he couldn't stop seeing it. The familiar comfort of his car felt like a thin metal skin against a world that had suddenly become abrasive and alien. The Maiden Stone had shown him the truth, but the truth was a migraine, a cacophony of adolescent angst and digital noise. This wasn’t a battle against a rival, it was a war against an entire philosophy of existence he had spent his life trying to ignore.

He parked in his usual spot behind the old post office, but the short walk back to his flat felt different. The granite walls of the town, which usually felt like the reassuring bones of an old friend, now seemed fragile, a heritage facade plastered over a hollow, modern core. In his attic, the quiet felt earned but precarious. The scent of beeswax and old paper was a comfort, but it was the comfort of a bygone era. He looked at his workbench, at the smooth river stones he used for scrying, the carefully bundled sprigs of rowan and gorse for protection, the hand-ground inks for writing wards. For a terrifying moment, they looked like relics, the tools of a dead trade. His craft, the slow, patient art of listening to the land, felt hopelessly archaic against the instant, screaming gratification of the magic he had just witnessed.

He shook the thought away with a shudder. It was a poison dart from the vision, an attempt to make him feel irrelevant. His magic was not dead; it was the land itself, and the land endured. This new blight was the mayfly, loud and frantic in its single day of life, while his craft was the granite it danced upon. But even granite could be worn down by a constant, irritating drip. He couldn't simply put up a ward and hope the problem went away. This wasn’t an attack, it was a contamination. A spiritual oil spill. He had to go to the source. He couldn't storm in, a wild-eyed wizard confronting a teenager in their bedroom. That would be disastrous, likely resulting in a panicked, uncontrolled magical backlash and a call to the police. No, he had to be a custodian. He had to survey the damage, understand the nature of the leak, and then, very carefully, try to turn off the tap.

The development was called Chapelton Fields. The name was a bitter irony, as the only field in sight was a manicured patch of green in the centre of the estate with a sterile-looking children's playground, and any chapel that might have once stood here was long since ploughed into memory. The houses were all variations on a theme, clad in a mix of pale brick and grey composite board, with identical postage-stamp lawns and flimsy panel fences. To Alistair’s senses, the entire estate was a psychic dead zone. The earth beneath had been scraped and sanitised, its history erased, its ley lines buried under concrete foundations and fibre-optic cables. The air hummed not with the slow breath of the Garioch, but with the frantic, overlapping signals of a hundred domestic wireless networks. It was a place with no stories, and the vacuum was being filled with noise.

He walked the curving streets, his flat cap pulled low, his hands deep in the pockets of his tweed jacket. He looked like any other resident's father, out for a bit of air. But beneath the mundane exterior, he was hunting. He let his senses skim the surface of the place, ignoring the overwhelming digital hum and searching for that specific magical signature. He was looking for the signal within the noise, the one sour note in the bland chorus. It was a discordant frequency of want, a selfish, grabbing energy that clawed at the world for attention. He passed rows of identical front doors, felt the faint, tired emanations of family life, of dinners being cooked and televisions watched. It was all shallow, but it was normal. He was looking for the abnormal.

He found it on a street called 'Standing Stone Way', the most offensive piece of marketing nomenclature he had yet encountered. The feeling was a spike of that greasy, impatient energy, a psychic whine that stood out from the background drone. It pulsed from a two-storey house distinguished only by a basketball hoop over the garage and a lawn that was starting to lose its battle with weeds. The energy wasn't flowing out in a smooth current; it was sputtering, like a faulty fluorescent light, in bursts of frustration and desperate wishing. He could feel it now, a chaotic jumble of half-formed spells and emotional static. *'I wish I was popular.' 'I wish they would notice me.' 'I wish something, anything, would happen.'* It was the magical equivalent of a tantrum, leaking out through the pristine white window frames and poisoning the air. He had found the source. He stood across the road, partially hidden by a spindly ornamental cherry tree, and watched the house. The fight had come to him, and it lived in Chapelton Fields, on Standing Stone Way, behind a door that was probably just like all the others. And he had absolutely no idea what to do next.

Chapter 2

For a long time, Alistair simply stood there, a tweed-clad ghost haunting the pristine pavement of Standing Stone Way. The house opposite was a blank face, its PVC windows like dead eyes. He was a man equipped to fight dragons, to bargain with the spirits of the drowned, and to soothe the restless dead. He had spells for mending broken stone and silencing malign echoes. He had no cantrip for dealing with a bored teenager who had discovered a grimoire on the internet. His entire arsenal of quiet, enduring craft felt useless, like bringing a beautifully carved yew bow to a drone fight. To storm the house would be a violation, an act of aggression that would define him as the villain. To do nothing was to let the spiritual infection fester. The sheer, daunting normalcy of the place was a better ward than any he could weave.

He turned and walked away, the sense of defeat a cold weight in his stomach. The perfectly curved road, the identical saplings planted at precise intervals, the unnerving quiet of a neighbourhood where no one was outside—it all felt like a conscious and aggressive rejection of the wild, tangled, history-soaked world he inhabited. This place wasn't just built on the land; it was built to deny it, to hold it at bay with tarmac, concrete, and chemically treated lawn. He felt a profound sense of loneliness, not for himself, but for the buried earth beneath his feet, which could no longer feel the rain or the turn of the seasons. The blight wasn't just the bad magic; it was the sterile ground from which it grew.

Back in his attic, he closed the heavy oak door and leaned against it, the familiar scent of beeswax, old paper, and dried herbs washing over him like a benediction. This was his territory, a space where every object had a story, every shadow held a memory. He went to his small kitchenette and began the ritual of making tea again, but this time with a fierce, deliberate concentration. He measured the loose-leaf Assam, heated the water in his old copper kettle until it sang its particular, familiar note, and poured it over the leaves, watching them unfurl. He was not scrying. He was re-establishing order, reminding himself of the slow, patient magic of process. He was taking back his morning, one deliberate action at a time. The first sip was a reclamation, a small victory against the chaos of the day.

Holding the warm mug, he sat in his worn leather armchair and looked out at the grey slate roofs of the old town. The problem, he reasoned, was not the power. Power was neutral; a river could turn a mill wheel or it could drown a village. The problem was the vessel. An untrained, unstable, and likely unhappy mind was directing forces it couldn't comprehend, for reasons it barely understood. It was the magical equivalent of a child finding a loaded handgun. To simply snatch it away would solve nothing; the child would only seek another, or their sense of grievance would curdle into something far more dangerous. You had to address the reason they were looking for a weapon in the first place. The loneliness. The desperation to be seen.

How, then, to approach the source without causing an explosion? He needed information, but the thought of using his own skills to spy on a teenager's private life felt deeply wrong. His craft was for listening to the land, not for peering through bedroom curtains. It would be a perversion of his own principles, a step onto the same path of convenience-over-consequence that this novice was on. No, the tools for this task had to be mundane. The thought came to him unbidden, accompanied by the remembered scent of lavender polish and the sound of a gently tutting voice. Mrs. Gable. She was the nexus of the town’s non-magical information network, a living archive of births, departures, disputes, and diagnoses. Her knowledge was vast, her methods subtle, and her price was a packet of shortbread and a patient ear.

The decision settled uneasily within him. He would become a gossip. He would trade pleasantries for intelligence. It felt grubby, a far cry from communing with ancient stones, but it was a human problem, and it required a human solution. He would need a pretext, a reason to be nosing around Chapelton Fields that would make sense to the mundane world. He could be a prospective buyer, perhaps, or claim to be tracing his family tree, looking for a connection to the old chapel the estate was named for. The lie felt awkward and ill-fitting in his mouth, but it was a necessary piece of camouflage. His work had always been about maintaining a balance, and now the balance required him to step out from the shadows of his esoteric world and onto the brightly-lit, unforgiving stage of neighbourhood life. The prospect was, in its own way, more frightening than the shriek of any cockerel.

The box of Walker’s shortbread felt absurdly conspicuous under Alistair’s arm, a tartan-clad Trojan horse for his expedition into the suburbs. He walked the short distance to Mrs. Gable’s bungalow, a route that took him past the butcher, the baker, and the small, independent bookshop where he occasionally sourced rare local histories. Each familiar storefront was a testament to the town's enduring character, a network of real-world connections that had existed long before the first fibre-optic cable was laid. Mrs. Gable, in her own way, was as much a part of that infrastructure as the granite kerbstones. Her bungalow sat on a quiet street of identical 1970s homes, each one distinguished by the personality of its garden. Hers was a riot of perfectly tended roses and fuchsias, a testament to order and dedication that Alistair could respect.

He rang the bell, which chimed a tinny but cheerful Westminster Quarters. A moment later the door opened, and Margaret Gable stood there, a small, bird-like woman with hair the colour of a winter sky and eyes as sharp and missed-nothing as a wren’s. She broke into a genuine smile upon seeing him, wiping her hands on her floral apron. "Alistair! What a lovely surprise. I was just about to put the kettle on. You're just in time, come away in." She ushered him into a living room that was the polar opposite of his attic. Where he had chaotic stacks of books and artefacts, she had pristine surfaces and a legion of ceramic animals on a polished Welsh dresser. The air smelled of lavender polish and the faint, sweet scent of baking. It was a space so thoroughly, unapologetically mundane that it felt like a fortress.

"I was just passing," Alistair lied, placing the offering of shortbread on the coffee table. "I thought you might like these."
"Oh, you shouldn't have," she said, though her hands were already reaching for the box. "That's my diet out the window for another week. Now, tea. You'll take it the usual way?" He nodded, sinking into a plush armchair that felt like it was trying to swallow him. As she bustled in the kitchen, he surveyed the room. On the mantelpiece, a row of photographs chronicled the lives of children and grandchildren, a testament to time measured in school portraits and wedding days, not the turning of constellations or the erosion of mountains. It was a different kind of history, more fragile but no less potent. Mrs. Gable was a keeper of bloodlines and birthdays, the archivist of the town’s heart.

She returned with a tray bearing a porcelain teapot, two matching cups, and a plate with the shortbread already arranged in a neat fan. She poured the tea with a practiced, steady hand. "So," she began, her eyes twinkling over the rim of her cup, "what's a man who usually only 'passes' by the standing stones and the riverbank doing in my neck of the woods?" There was no malice in the question, only a keen, undisguised curiosity. She knew his habits. Of course she did. Alistair felt a flush of heat rise up his neck. His carefully prepared pretext about researching the old chapel suddenly felt flimsy and foolish. He decided on a modified truth, something closer to his real anxieties.

"I was out for a walk," he began, swirling the tea in his cup. "Out towards the new estates. Chapelton Fields." He made a small, dismissive gesture. "It's… a different world out there, isn't it? So new. I was wondering what kind of folk are moving in. If they feel like they're part of Inverurie, or just… camping next to it." It was a sentiment she could understand, an appeal to her role as a social historian. Her expression softened with understanding. "Ah, I know exactly what you mean. It's a strange place. No heart to it yet. All young families, mostly. Folk who work offshore, or commuters to the city. Nice enough, but they keep to themselves. They do their big shop at the superstore, they drive everywhere. It's not like the old town."

She took a biscuit and nibbled on it thoughtfully, her mind flicking through its vast card-catalogue of local knowledge. "There are a few that stand out, mind you. There's a family in that new bit they call Standing Stone Way—can you believe the cheek of it?—the Mitchells. Moved up from England about a year back. He works in IT, I think. Very quiet. They have a daughter. Chloe. My Brenda’s girl, Fiona, is in her year at the Academy. Says she’s a bit of a loner. One of those goth types, you know? All black clothes and moody looks. Spends all her time in her room on that internet." Alistair kept his expression neutral, but his heart gave a heavy thump. Chloe. The name landed in the room with the weight of a stone. This was it. The source was no longer an abstract energy signature; it was a teenage girl in a new house, alienated and misunderstood.

"She sounds like she's having a hard time of it," Alistair said, the words feeling surprisingly genuine. Mrs. Gable nodded, her sharp curiosity momentarily replaced by a universal, grandmotherly sympathy. "It's a difficult age. And a difficult thing, to be uprooted like that. It’s hard to put down roots in soil that’s barely had time to settle." She said it as a simple observation, but for Alistair, the metaphor struck with the force of a revelation. That was the absolute heart of it. The girl was trying to put down roots, but the ground was sterile. So she had tried to create her own, using the only tools she could find: cheap, synthetic, and instantly gratifying. He finished his tea, the conversation drifting to more mundane topics—the dreich weather, the scandalous price of fish, the upcoming town gala. He listened and nodded, but his mind was miles away, on Standing Stone Way, grappling with a problem that had just become infinitely more complex and delicate.

Walking back to his flat, the grey afternoon felt heavy with unspoken things. He had what he needed, but the knowledge brought no relief, only a heavier sense of responsibility. The enemy he had imagined—a lazy, disrespectful dabbler—had dissolved, replaced by the far more pitiable figure of a lonely girl. You couldn't declare war on loneliness. You couldn't weave a ward against adolescent angst. The methods he had contemplated, of cleansing and banishing, now seemed brutish and cruel. He felt a pang of something akin to guilt. He, who drew power from the deep-rooted history of this place, had never once considered the plight of those transplanted into its rootless fringes. He had been a custodian for the soul of the old town, but had ignored the creeping soullessness on its borders.

Back in the sanctuary of his attic, he didn't make tea. He went to a large, flat-topped wooden chest that sat beneath the dormer window. It was made of driftwood, worn smooth and silver by the sea, and it was where he kept his finds—objects that were not tools of his craft, but simply pieces of the world that had spoken to him. Things that held a quiet magic of their own. He lifted the heavy lid. The scent of salt, dry stone, and time rolled out. He ran his fingers over the contents: a spiral ammonite fossil, a shard of Roman pottery from the fort at Normandykes, a twisted piece of rowan that had grown in the shape of a bird. These were objects saturated with story. He was searching for something specific now, a piece of counter-magic not for Chloe’s spells, but for her worldview. He needed an antidote to the disposable, a quiet rebellion against the synthetic.

His fingers closed around a stone. It was a piece of grey granite, no bigger than his palm, but centuries in the river had worn it perfectly smooth and, crucially, had bored a small, clean hole right through its centre. A hag stone. A window into the other world, a talisman of protection, a symbol of seeing things differently. It held the patient, relentless power of the River Don, the immense, geological time of the granite, and the whispered folklore of generations. It was everything the plastic bag was not: natural, ancient, unique, and full of silent meaning. It was an invitation. He held the stone in his hand, its cool, solid weight a comfort against his palm. He couldn't confront Chloe, and he couldn't lecture her. But he could leave this for her to find. A breadcrumb, a clue. He could seed her sterile, modern world with a single, undeniable piece of the real one, and hope that a girl who was searching for magic might recognise it when she saw it. His battle plan had changed. It was no longer about fighting the blight. It was about planting a garden in the wasteland.

Chapter 3

The following evening, as twilight bled purple and grey into the sky over Inverurie, Alistair prepared for his delicate mission. The hag stone lay on his workbench, a dark, smooth void amidst the clutter of his life. He had spent the day in quiet contemplation, shoring up his own magical reserves, not with grand rituals but with small, grounding acts: polishing his walking boots until the leather gleamed, carefully sharpening the pencils he used for charting ley lines, and brewing a pot of Lapsang Souchong whose smoky scent filled the attic and reminded him of peat fires and autumn nights. These were the rites of a craftsman, and they settled his mind. He was not going into battle; he was undertaking an act of cultivation, a task requiring a gardener's patience, not a soldier's steel. He picked up the stone. Its cold, solid weight was a familiar comfort, a concentration of everything he valued: time, water, stone, and the touch of unseen worlds. He slipped it into the deep pocket of his tweed jacket, where it settled against his hip like a small, secret anchor.

His drive to Chapelton Fields was different this time. The orange glow of the streetlights cast long, distorted shadows, making the uniform houses look even more unreal, like a film set after the cast and crew had gone home. The digital hum of the place was quieter now, subsumed into the domestic thrum of evening. Televisions flickered blue through downstairs windows, and the air carried the faint, mingled smells of a hundred different dinners. His earlier revulsion had mellowed into a kind of melancholy pity. This wasn't a fortress of evil; it was a dormitory, a place people returned to after their real lives elsewhere. It was a landscape of deep, pervasive numbness, and he was about to introduce a single, sharp point of feeling. He parked at the far end of Standing Stone Way, in the shadow of a high wooden fence that marked the boundary of the estate, and he waited.

He did not have to wait long. The front door of the Mitchell house opened, spilling a rectangle of warm, yellow light onto the manicured lawn. A figure emerged, silhouetted against the light before stepping into the gloaming and pulling the door shut behind her. Chloe. She wore black jeans, a black hoodie with the hood pulled up, and a pair of oversized headphones that seemed to serve as both armour and insulation from the world. In the half-light, with her pale face and deliberate, almost drifting gait, she looked like a spirit who had lost her way. She didn’t turn towards the sterile playground or the other houses. Instead, she set off down the pavement in his direction, heading for the edge of the estate, the borderlands where the new development frayed into the ancient countryside. Alistair sank lower in his seat, his heart beating a slow, steady rhythm. The prey was moving. The hunter, or rather, the gardener, watched.

He gave her a two-minute lead before quietly getting out of his car and following on foot. His soft-soled boots made no sound on the pavement. He was a creature of the twilight, accustomed to moving through the world without disturbing it. He watched as Chloe reached the end of the road, where the neat pavement gave way to a rough farm track. A five-bar metal gate blocked the path, and beyond it lay a dark, sleeping field that sloped down towards the distant, glittering lights of the old town. This was clearly her place. She didn't climb the gate, but leaned against it, her arms resting on the cold top bar. She took off her headphones, letting them hang around her neck, and for the first time, she seemed to be listening to the world around her—the distant hum of traffic on the bypass, the rustle of the wind in the overgrown hedgerow, the vast quiet of the sky. She stood there for a long time, a lonely sentinel at the border of two worlds. Alistair watched, hidden in the deep shadow of the boundary fence, and felt a profound ache of recognition. He, too, had his places of quiet contemplation. He understood the need for a threshold.

Eventually, with a sigh that the wind carried to him, she pushed herself away from the gate and put her headphones back on, the spell broken. She retraced her steps, her head bowed, disappearing back into the anonymous geometry of the estate. Alistair waited until the front door of her house had clicked shut before he emerged from the shadows. He walked to the gate, the air growing colder as the last of the light failed. The metal was frigid beneath his hand. This was the spot. It was her altar, her lookout post. He took the hag stone from his pocket. The river-smoothness of it was a stark contrast to the cold, painted metal of the gate. He didn't just place it on the top bar. He held it for a moment, pushing a quiet intention into it. Not a command, not a compulsion, but an offering. He whispered a single, ancient word for 'see', and then he carefully, precisely, wedged the stone into a small gap between the gate's hinge and the thick wooden post it was hung on. It was not obvious. It would not be seen by a casual passer-by. But someone who leaned on that gate, someone who ran their hands along its length as they stared out at the night, would find it. Their fingers would brush against the impossible smoothness of the stone, discover the strange, perfect hole, and wonder.

He stepped back, his work done. The stone was almost invisible in the darkness, a tiny piece of authentic magic hidden in plain sight, a secret waiting to be discovered. He had cast his line, baited not with power but with mystery. He turned and walked back to his car, feeling neither triumphant nor relieved, but suspended in a state of profound uncertainty. He had planted a seed of the true world in a plastic garden. Now all he could do was wait and see if it would be strong enough to take root.

The days that followed were a quiet torment. Alistair found his own finely-tuned senses working against him, every subtle shift in the town’s atmosphere setting his nerves on edge. He would be walking down West High Street and a sudden wave of static from a shop’s security sensor would make him flinch, thinking the grubby magic had returned. He tried to scry the surface of his morning tea and saw only his own anxious face reflected in the dark liquid. The waiting was an abrasive cloth, rubbing raw his connection to the world. He was a man used to the geological patience of stone and the cyclical certainty of the seasons, but he had introduced a chaotic human element into the equation, and the suspense was a tax on his soul. He fought the constant, nagging urge to drive back to Chapelton Fields, to check on his offering, but he knew that would be a mistake. To hover was to interfere. The seed had to be left in the dark to germinate on its own terms.

He forced himself to follow his routines, knowing the familiar rhythms were the only anchor he had. He took another walk to the Bass, and this time the sickness on the hill had receded further. The grass was losing its aggressive, unnatural vibrancy, and the humming thrum of stored time, though still weak, felt clearer, as if a layer of grime had been washed away by a slow, gentle rain. The land was healing itself, as it always did, but the process was slow, painstaking, and vulnerable. The memory of the plastic bag and its greasy aura was a scar on the place, a reminder of how easily and carelessly such wounds could be inflicted. It solidified his resolve. His methods might be slow, but they worked with the grain of the world, not against it. His magic was an act of mending, and mending took time.

He was in his attic two evenings later, cataloguing a collection of river-tumbled pottery shards, when it happened. It was not a sound or a flash of light, but a sudden and profound change in the psychic pressure of the world. For weeks, the background hum of Inverurie had been tainted by that persistent, whining static from Chapelton Fields, a constant, low-level irritant like a mosquito in a dark room. Now, in an instant, it was gone. The silence it left behind was so absolute, so pure, that Alistair froze, his hand hovering over a piece of medieval earthenware. He lifted his head, his senses straining. The psychic whine hadn't just faded; it had been extinguished, as if a switch had been thrown. The chaotic, leaking tantrum of power had stopped. Alistair held his breath, his heart hammering not with fear, but with a sudden, sharp, electrifying anticipation. She had found it.

Slowly, carefully, he extended his senses, letting his awareness drift like smoke through the streets of the town and out towards the new estate. The air tasted clean again. The oppressive blanket of noise was gone, and he could once more feel the individual threads of energy that made up his home—the deep, slow pulse of the confluence of the rivers, the ancient sleep of the Pictish stones, even the mundane, collective sigh of a town settling down for the night. He focused on the house on Standing Stone Way. The messy, sputtering leak was gone. In its place, emanating from the same spot, was something new. It was a single, pure note of focused inquiry. It was the energy of a mind utterly captivated, a quiet, intense hum of wonder. The desperate, outward-shouted pleas for attention had been replaced by a deep, internal question. Chloe was no longer trying to force a change upon the world; she was examining a piece of it with an attention so complete it was a spell in itself.

A slow smile touched Alistair’s lips, the first genuine one in days. It had worked. It had worked better than he could have dared to hope. He had not banished the darkness; he had offered a candle. He had not fought the student; he had given her a new, and better, textbook. He looked around his cluttered attic, at the tools of his quiet, enduring craft. The gorse bundles, the scrying stones, the hand-written charts of lunar cycles. They did not seem like relics anymore. They felt like the future. She felt a desperate, primal urge to run, to put as much distance as possible between herself and that neat, tidy house of horrors, but Alistair’s steady, plodding pace beside her was a silent command to maintain their cover, to show no panic, to walk like a normal person through a world that was no longer normal at all.

The drive back to the old town was thick with a silence that was heavier than any words. Chloe stared out the window, watching the identical houses of the new estate give way to the unique, time-worn granite faces of Inverurie. The journey felt like travelling between dimensions. One world was a sterile, brightly-lit labyrinth where monsters hid behind cheerful front doors and immaculate gardens. The other was a place of deep shadows and ancient power, where at least the dangers were honest in their nature. For the first time, she felt a flicker of the deep love Alistair had for his world of stone and water; it was a messy, complex, and often sorrowful place, but it was authentic. It did not lie about what it was. The weight of her new reality pressed down on her, the simple, terrifying fact that the source of the spiritual sickness, the enemy they were hunting, lived just a few doors down from the bedroom where she had slept since moving here.

Back in the sanctuary of the attic, Alistair moved immediately to the kettle. The ritual of making tea was no longer just a comfort; it was a necessary act of magical and psychological decontamination, a way to wash the sterile wrongness of Chapelton Fields from their minds. He worked with a heavy, deliberate focus, and when he handed Chloe her mug, she took it with both hands, less for the warmth and more for the solid, grounding reality of the object itself. The fragrant steam rose between them, a small, good thing in a room that suddenly felt like a bunker in a long and difficult war. Chloe finally found her voice, the words spilling out in a shaky, hushed torrent.

"It's the Hendersons. The house, I mean. They moved in about six months ago. He works in logistics, I think. She's a dental hygienist. They have a son, he's a couple of years younger than me. He seems… normal. Quiet. The man I saw in the window, Mr. Henderson, he waves. He waves when he's washing his car on a Sunday." The sheer, banal detail of it made her voice crack. This wasn't some shadowy figure in a black robe; it was a man who washed his car and waved at his neighbours. The horror was in the utter absence of anything horrific.

Alistair listened, his expression grim, his fingers steepled around his own mug. He did not dismiss her observations, but processed them, filed them away. "The face at the window is not always the hand that holds the knife," he said, his voice a low rumble. "It could be him. It could be his wife. It could be the boy. It could even be that the house itself is merely the terminal, the point of connection, and the operator is somewhere else entirely, using them as an anchor." He let that chilling possibility settle in the air. "What we know for certain is that this is the nest. And we cannot simply set fire to it."

He leaned forward, the strategist taking over from the exhausted field operative. "My craft is one of stone and sorrow. I can read the memory of a battlefield and soothe the anger of a drowned man. But I cannot scry a man's credit card statements or know what forums he visits in the dead of night. This enemy hides in the mundane, in the digital noise, in the places my magic has no purchase. We have reached the limit of my tools, Chloe." His admission was a profound moment, a confession of fallibility from the man she had come to see as an unshakable bastion of ancient power. He was telling her that his magic, the deep, enduring craft of the land, was ill-equipped for this new kind of fight.

"So we must use your tools," he continued, his gaze intense. "Or rather, the tools of your world." He gestured vaguely, a motion that encompassed the phone she had set on the table, the entire sprawling, invisible network of the internet, the complex social web of a modern suburb. "I need intelligence. I need to know everything about the Hendersons. What are their routines? Who are their friends? Are there any cracks in that perfect facade? Any signs of stress, of discord, of a secret life? You live there. You are my eyes and ears inside their territory. Your new task is not to hunt for magic, but for the mundane clues that will lead us to the magician. You are no longer just a sentry. You are a spy."

Chloe stared at him, the full weight of his request settling upon her. He was asking her to watch her neighbours, to pry into their lives, to search for the darkness behind the polite smiles and the manicured lawn. It felt like a gross violation, a step into a world of grubby secrets and suspicion. But it was also the only path forward. She thought of the sickened hill, the unraveling ward, the terror she had felt by the river. The enemy had brought the war to her street. She had no choice but to fight back with the weapons she had. As she looked at Alistair, at the deep, weary hope in his eyes, she knew her answer. The quiet life she had once longed for was gone forever. In its place was a secret, a purpose, and a war to be fought, not in the haunted woods, but across the garden fences of Standing Stone Way.
